titleStmt.title: Despatch from J. Milton Turner to Frederick W. Seward, August 23, 1877

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: Despatch from J. Milton Turner to Frederick W. Seward
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States
Republic of Liberia

J. Milton Turner
To the Department of State,
Washington
Subject:
Concerning the Commercial Agency of Edina, Grand Bassa.
Enclosures:
No. 1. Copy of Letter from H. L. Cruesoe, Edina, Grand Bassa
No. 2. Copy of Letter to Hon J. J. Cheeseman from the Legation

Consulate General of the United States.
Monrovia, Liberia 23rd Aug. 1877.
Sir,

I have the honor to inform the Department that during the months of Mar. or April I addressed a note to Mr. H. L. Crusoe, in his capacity of Commercial Agent of the United States, at Grand Bassa, in which I requested that gentleman to spare for my use whenever it is necessary for me to travel by row-boat, one of the small
Honorable
F. W. Seward
Assistant Secretary of State
Washington
small American Flags belonging to the Commercial Agency at that point.

A copy of Mr. Crusoe's reply to me, in which that gentleman informs me that he has resigned the office of Commercial Agent of the United States, and given the Archives of the Agency into the possession of Mr. Cheeseman, is transmitted herewith, marked Enclosure No. 1.

I wrote to Mr. Crusoe the second time, requesting him to explain, for my information, the circumstances of his resignation as mentioned by himself in Enclosure No. 1. of this despatch. After waiting in vain a reasonable time for an explination from
from Mr. Crusoe, I addressed a note of inquiry to Mr. Cheeseman. That note was dated 16 July and a copy thereof is enclosed (marked No. 2.) and transmitted herewith.

Not having received a reply from Mr. Crusoe nor from Mr. Cheeseman up to the present time of writing, I regard it my duty to visit Bassa and, in person investigate the circumstances. Hence I shall go thither, the interests of the Government permitting thereof, by the first conveyance leaving Monrovia for that point.

Meanwhile I shall hope to have the honor to thank the Department for whatever information or instruction that is proper to be extended to
to me in the matter.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your Obedient Servant
J Milton Turner
Edina, May 7, 1877

His Excellency
J. Milton Turner
U.S.M.R. & Con. Genl.
Monrovia.
Sir,

I have the honor of your note of in which you request to be accomodated with a "Union Jack" flag for your boat purposes. Having resigned the post of U.S. Com. Agent and turned over Archives and effects to Hon. Mr. Cheeseman. I am unable to serve you as I should take great pleasure in doing had I the power.
Begging that you will accept the assurance of my continued respect and good wishes.

I
I am,
Sir,
Your very obd servant
(Sd) H. L. Crusoe
Pardon the delay of this answer I have been for several weeks absent from home.
(Sd) H. L. C.

Legation of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia 16 July 1877.
Sir;

Honorable H. L. Crusoe informed me a few days since that he has resigned the office of United States Commercial Agent of Grand Bassa, and that you are in charge of the Archives, and I suppose acting incumbent of that position. You would oblige me by informing me by mail if you have received from the Government at Washington an appointment
Hon. J. J. Cheeseman
Edina, Grand Bassa.
appointment to that office, and if so then have you been officially recognized in that capacity by the Government at Monrovia.

I am,
Sir,
Very Respectfully
(Sd) J. Milton Turner
U.S. Minister
